Award.AwardTitle: Enforced Stacking of Shape-Persistent Macrocycles: A Molecular Approach for Tuning the Structures and Functions of Nanotubular Assemblies
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Bing Gong of the State University of New York at Buffalo and Xiao Cheng Zeng of the University of Nebraska at Lincoln will develop a general strategy for the controlled synthesis and assembly of shape-persistent macrocyclic molecules into functional organic nanotubes containing sub-nanometer pores. Because the interior and exterior of the macrocycles may be functionalized independently, both the diameters and inner surfaces of the nanopores may be modified in a controlled manner. The nanopores, eventually, will be incorporated into membranes and allow for the selective transport of water across the membrane. The broader impacts involve cross-disciplinary training of graduate and undergraduate students, incorporating research into teaching, outreach to students at primarily undergraduate institutions, and the potential long term impacts of water purification technology.

Pores of various diameters are found in a range of synthetic and natural objects. For example, water purification technologies utilize porous membranes that permit the selective passage of water over the other salt and organic components. In biology, cell membranes contain protein pore structures that select for the transport of specific molecules and ions and contain active functions that are far more advanced than synthetic pores. This research project will enhance our understanding of how to prepare and assemble molecules into pores that permit the transport of one type of molecule, such as water. The research will impact our fundamental knowledge of chemistry in this area, yet may have direct application to various technologies that utilize porous materials, such as water purification. This project also will provide mechanisms to educate undergraduate and graduate at the frontiers and interfaces of molecular, biological, and physical sciences.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Buffalo
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project supported by NSF (CHE-1306326) aimed to establish the tubular stacking of shape-persistent macrocycles based on the enforcement provided by highly-directional, multiple hydrogen bonding interactions that are encoded into the molecular building blocks. The completion of the proposed research aims has led to the (1) creation of a synthetic method that allows the preparation of a host of shape-persistent macrocyclic molecular building blocks that share the same periphery bearing the same set of hydrogen-bonding side chains but differ in the functional groups placed into their inner cavities; (2) confirmation of the generality of hydrogen bond-enforced tubular stacking of the designed rigid macrocycles; (3) realization of mix-assembly of macrocyclic molecules having inner cavities with different functional groups; (4) exploration of some of the tubular assemblies for their behavior in mediating ion transport across the lipid bilayer (cell membrane) and in serving as self-assembling tube-like molecules for rod-like guest molecules. This research resulted in seveteen publications (out of 26 publications) from the co-PI’s group and 3 from the co-PI’s group, many in leading journals such as Journal of the American Chemical Society, Angwandte Chemie, Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, Chemical Science, and Accounts of Chemical Research, and had attracted wide attention. Results from this research have provided answers to fundamental questions on the role of non-covalent interactions in driving the formation of well-order suporamolecular structures and practical. The obtained outcome also offers a new supramolecular system with great practical potentials. For example, the demonstrated ability to alter the functions the inner pores of tubular assemblies by incorporating synthetic accessible molecular building blocks provides a powerful means for constructing molecular and ion channels that can be tailored for transporting specific molecules and ions, which would be tremendously useful and beneficial for areas such as the development of therapeutics and materials for separation. This project has provided the opportunity for training students and postodocs. Five undergraduate students, eight graduate students, and two postdocs from the PI’s lab, three graduate students and three postdocs from the co-PI’s lab had participated in this research.


Last Modified: 10/31/2017
Modified by: Bing Gong
